articles.headline: Lesson Plan From a Departing Schools Chief
articles.snippet: More than a decade ago Joel I. Klein fought a monopoly, Microsoft. He took on another kind of monopoly when he became New York’s schools chief.
articles.abstract: More than a decade ago Joel I. Klein fought a monopoly, Microsoft. He took on another kind of monopoly when he became New York’s schools chief.
articles.lead_paragraph: “This isn’t rocket science,” Joel I. Klein was saying, too modestly.

articles.headline: ‘Smart’ Meters Draw Complaints of Inaccuracy
articles.snippet: Whether smart electric meters are ripping off consumers by overstating electricity use is now a matter of debate.
articles.abstract: Whether smart electric meters are ripping off consumers by overstating electricity use is now a matter of debate.
articles.lead_paragraph: NOLANVILLE, Tex.  Sgt. John Robertson 2nd, an Army mechanic at nearby Fort Hood, is fuming about the so-called smart electric meter his local utility has installed on the side of his tidy, 1,800-square-foot home.

articles.headline: Rebuilding Lags in Pakistan Area After Offensive
articles.snippet: A lack of progress after the military’s campaign against the Taliban has raised fears of renewed militancy.
articles.abstract: A lack of progress after the military’s campaign against the Taliban has raised fears of renewed militancy.
articles.lead_paragraph: DRUSHKHELA, Pakistan  People here felt a surge of optimism last year when the military declared the Swat Valley cleared of Taliban insurgents, who had bullied their way to power by publicly whipping and beheading opponents.

articles.headline: Newsweek’s Printing Press Was a Top Draw for Diller
articles.snippet: Seeing long odds for a profit at The Daily Beast, which is losing about $10 million a year, Barry Diller became increasingly interested in Newsweek.
articles.abstract: Seeing long odds for a profit at The Daily Beast, which is losing about $10 million a year, Barry Diller became increasingly interested in Newsweek.
articles.lead_paragraph: Barry Diller, who has spent the better part of a decade amassing a collection of Internet companies — a search engine here, a dating Web site there — has figured out how to help make the Internet work a little better for him. He is going into the magazine business.

articles.headline: When a Safety Net Is Yanked Away
articles.snippet: Plan for the possibility of long-term care costs, but don’t assume that insurance will be the guaranteed answer.
articles.abstract: Plan for the possibility of long-term care costs, but don’t assume that insurance will be the guaranteed answer.
articles.lead_paragraph: November is long-term care awareness month, and to celebrate, a big player in the long-term care insurance industry announced on Thursday that it wanted to get as far away from the business as possible.

articles.headline: Defying Trend, Canada Lures More Migrants
articles.snippet: Manitoba has won new power to bring foreigners in, handpicking ethnic and occupational groups.
articles.abstract: Manitoba has won new power to bring foreigners in, handpicking ethnic and occupational groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: WINNIPEG, Manitoba — As waves of immigrants from the developing world remade Canada a decade ago, the famously friendly people of Manitoba could not contain their pique.

articles.headline: Taking Aim at the Mortgage Tax Break
articles.snippet: A presidential commission’s proposal to end the mortgage tax break, a very sacred cow, seeks to emphasize the deficit’s severity to the middle class.
articles.abstract: A presidential commission’s proposal to end the mortgage tax break, a very sacred cow, seeks to emphasize the deficit’s severity to the middle class.
articles.lead_paragraph: By proposing to curtail the tax deduction for mortgage interest, the president’s deficit commission is sounding an alarm.

articles.headline: I.R.S. Sits on Data Pointing to Missing Children
articles.snippet: Privacy laws prevent the I.R.S. from disclosing data that could be helpful in finding missing children.
articles.abstract: Privacy laws prevent the I.R.S. from disclosing data that could be helpful in finding missing children.
articles.lead_paragraph: For parents of missing children, any scrap of information that could lead to an abductor is precious.

articles.headline: Briton Loses Twitter Case, but Wins Following
articles.snippet: Paul J. Chambers’s joke on Twitter about blowing up an airport got him convicted, but he is now a cause célèbre.
articles.abstract: Paul J. Chambers’s joke on Twitter about blowing up an airport got him convicted, but he is now a cause célèbre.
articles.lead_paragraph: DONCASTER, England  The troubles of Paul J. Chambers began on a cold night in January, when his attempt to visit a woman from Northern Ireland he had met online was thwarted by a snowstorm that grounded flights at his local airport. Mr. Chambers’s first reaction, as in many things in his life, was to address the issue on Twitter.

articles.headline: Looking to 2012, Republicans Vie for Big Donors
articles.snippet: Some potential candidates are pursuing outsize contributions using state political action committees, which, unlike federal PACs, have no spending limits.
articles.abstract: Some potential candidates are pursuing outsize contributions using state political action committees, which, unlike federal PACs, have no spending limits.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney is not running for president, yet. But a handful of big donors have each contributed in the realm of $100,000, or more, to Mr. Romney this year through a network of state political action committees he has set up that enable him to avoid federal campaign finance limits.

articles.headline: Municipal Bond Market Shudders
articles.snippet: While the declines were relatively small, the bond slump was swift enough to leave investors wondering if this was a brief setback or the start of something worse.
articles.abstract: While the declines were relatively small, the bond slump was swift enough to leave investors wondering if this was a brief setback or the start of something worse.
articles.lead_paragraph: Has the reckoning arrived for municipal bonds?

articles.headline: Burmese Dissident Is Freed After Long Detention
articles.snippet: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, a Nobel Peace laureate who was confined 15 of the last 21 years, was freed from house arrest.
articles.abstract: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, a Nobel Peace laureate who was confined 15 of the last 21 years, was freed from house arrest.
articles.lead_paragraph: YANGON, Myanmar — Myanmar’s pro-democracy leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, was freed from house arrest on Saturday, setting her on the path to a possible new confrontation with the generals who had kept her out of the public eye for 15 of the past 21 years.

articles.headline: Zagat Survey Aims to Regain Its Online Balance
articles.snippet: The founders of Zagat Survey hope that the rise of apps will help prove its pay model correct.
articles.abstract: The founders of Zagat Survey hope that the rise of apps will help prove its pay model correct.
articles.lead_paragraph: BACK in the early ’80s, when the Zagat Survey was still just a single sheet of legal-size paper that Nina and Tim Zagat gave to friends and colleagues, they learned that their list of the best restaurants in New York had been reproduced — en masse — inside Citibank.

articles.headline: At Ambac, Haves and Have-Nots
articles.snippet: A group of mortgage investors at Ambac Financial say a Wisconsin bankruptcy plan gives them second-class treatment.
articles.abstract: A group of mortgage investors at Ambac Financial say a Wisconsin bankruptcy plan gives them second-class treatment.
articles.lead_paragraph: LIFE is unfair, as everyone knows.

articles.headline: Can Microlending Save Haiti?
articles.snippet: Since the January earthquake, microbanks are struggling to keep credit flowing to Haitians who depend on loans to remain self-sufficient.
articles.abstract: Since the January earthquake, microbanks are struggling to keep credit flowing to Haitians who depend on loans to remain self-sufficient.
articles.lead_paragraph: Léogâne, Haiti

articles.headline: Cigarette Giants in Global Fight on Tighter Rules
articles.snippet: Tobacco companies are stepping up efforts around the world to fight tough restrictions on the marketing of cigarettes.
articles.abstract: Tobacco companies are stepping up efforts around the world to fight tough restrictions on the marketing of cigarettes.
articles.lead_paragraph: As sales to developing nations become ever more important to giant tobacco companies, they are stepping up efforts around the world to fight tough restrictions on the marketing of cigarettes.

articles.headline: A Journey From Lawmaker to Lobbyist and Back Again
articles.snippet: The Republican wave will sweep Dan Coats back into the Capitol Hill fold after years advancing companies’ interests.
articles.abstract: The Republican wave will sweep Dan Coats back into the Capitol Hill fold after years advancing companies’ interests.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  When Cooper Industries, a century-old manufacturing company based in Texas, moved its headquarters to Bermuda to slash its American income tax bill, it had to turn to a Washington insider with extraordinary contacts to soothe a seething Congress.

articles.headline: Nazis Were Given ‘Safe Haven’ in U.S., Report Says
articles.snippet: A report, which the Justice Department has tried to keep secret, provides new evidence about notorious Nazi cases.
articles.abstract: A report, which the Justice Department has tried to keep secret, provides new evidence about notorious Nazi cases.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A secret history of the United States government’s Nazi-hunting operation concludes that American intelligence officials created a “safe haven” in the United States for Nazis and their collaborators after World War II, and it details decades of clashes, often hidden, with other nations over war criminals here and abroad.

articles.headline: A 90-Day Bet on Mideast Talks
articles.snippet: A pledge by Israel to push for a freeze on some settlement building is an effort to keep the Palestinians at peace talks.
articles.abstract: A pledge by Israel to push for a freeze on some settlement building is an effort to keep the Palestinians at peace talks.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM  The pledge by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to push for a new, one-time-only freeze of 90 days on settlement construction in the West Bank represents a bet by the Israelis and the Americans that enough can be accomplished so that the Palestinians will not abandon peace talks even after the freeze ends.
articles.byline: By Ethan Bronner and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Ireland Rejects European Bailout Efforts
articles.snippet: The Irish government has insisted it does not see the need for a bailout from Europe, but speculation that one will be necessary has driven bond yields to ever-higher levels.
articles.abstract: The Irish government has insisted it does not see the need for a bailout from Europe, but speculation that one will be necessary has driven bond yields to ever-higher levels.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European ministers worked over the weekend on a financial rescue plan for Ireland, as pressure mounted on Dublin to seek a bailout to prevent the markets from spreading turbulence to other European countries, officials said on Sunday.
articles.byline: By James Kanter and Stephen Castle

articles.headline: Great Holiday Expectations for E-Readers
articles.snippet: Not many book buyers have an e-reader, but publishers and booksellers expect this holiday season to change that.
articles.abstract: Not many book buyers have an e-reader, but publishers and booksellers expect this holiday season to change that.
articles.lead_paragraph: This could be the holiday season that American shoppers and e-readers are properly introduced.

articles.headline: App to Tailor News Streams Gets Boost
articles.snippet: The company behind the app, Pulse News Reader, plans to announce that it has raised $800,000 in venture capital, and its product will now be free.
articles.abstract: The company behind the app, Pulse News Reader, plans to announce that it has raised $800,000 in venture capital, and its product will now be free.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif.  Publishers’ offices at print newspapers and magazines are tension-filled places these days, as executives watch readers and advertisers flock to the Web and cellphone screens.

articles.headline: Investors Put Money on Lawsuits to Get Payouts
articles.snippet: Investors are bankrolling other people’s lawsuits in the hope of sharing in the winnings.
articles.abstract: Investors are bankrolling other people’s lawsuits in the hope of sharing in the winnings.
articles.lead_paragraph: Large banks, hedge funds and private investors hungry for new and lucrative opportunities are bankrolling other people’s lawsuits, pumping hundreds of millions of dollars into medical malpractice claims, divorce battles and class actions against corporations  all in the hope of sharing in the potential winnings.

articles.headline: A School Fights for Life in Battered Haiti
articles.snippet: Nonpublic schools like the Collège Classique Féminin, central to a post-earthquake plan for education, remain largely unfunded.
articles.abstract: Nonpublic schools like the Collège Classique Féminin, central to a post-earthquake plan for education, remain largely unfunded.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  In mid-October, when fresh-faced girls in starched uniforms skipped through the gates of the Collège Classique Féminin to start the first post-earthquake school year, their desire to seek sanctuary inside was palpable.

articles.headline: U.S. Plan Envisions Path to Ending Afghan Combat
articles.snippet: A four-year plan to wind down American and allied fighting in Afghanistan by 2014 will be presented at a NATO meeting.
articles.abstract: A four-year plan to wind down American and allied fighting in Afghanistan by 2014 will be presented at a NATO meeting.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration has developed a plan to begin transferring security duties in select areas of Afghanistan to that country’s forces over the next 18 to 24 months, with an eye toward ending the American combat mission there by 2014, officials said Sunday.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Rod Nordland

articles.headline: As Studios Cut Back, Investors See Opening
articles.snippet: With studios reluctant to finance movies, investors are stepping in. And with state incentives and rights sales, they are doing nicely.
articles.abstract: With studios reluctant to finance movies, investors are stepping in. And with state incentives and rights sales, they are doing nicely.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  When Timmy Thompson, who made a lot of his money in oil field services, took a close look at the movie business a couple of years ago, he saw companies folding, credit collapsing and talent knocked down a peg in the aftermath of a labor war.

articles.headline: G.M. Retirees Weigh Buying Its Stock Again
articles.snippet: Thousands of former workers whose stock in the carmaker was wiped out must decide whether to buy shares again.
articles.abstract: Thousands of former workers whose stock in the carmaker was wiped out must decide whether to buy shares again.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  John Christie, who worked for 36 years building Chevrolet and Cadillac cars, once thought owning General Motors stock was a safe bet.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: Years Later, Armey Once Again a Power in Congress
articles.snippet: Dick Armey, who helped build the Tea Party wave, has been operating like a shadow majority leader.
articles.abstract: Dick Armey, who helped build the Tea Party wave, has been operating like a shadow majority leader.
articles.lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE  Dick Armey was drinking in the love.
articles.byline: By Kate Zernike and Jennifer Steinhauer

articles.headline: Newsweek Weds Daily Beast? Good Luck With That
articles.snippet: Putting together The Daily Beast and Newsweek makes no sense financially or editorially. Still, it could be fun to watch.
articles.abstract: Putting together The Daily Beast and Newsweek makes no sense financially or editorially. Still, it could be fun to watch.
articles.lead_paragraph: Putting together The Daily Beast and Newsweek makes little financial sense, includes not much in the way of editorial synergies  is it The News Beast or The Daily Week?  and marries two properties that have almost nothing in common other than the fact that they both lose lots of money.

articles.headline: For Whistle-Blowers, Expanded Incentives
articles.snippet: Congress and financial-market regulators are offering big payouts for tips about securities and commodity law violations, but some say they will make it harder for companies to police themselves.
articles.abstract: Congress and financial-market regulators are offering big payouts for tips about securities and commodity law violations, but some say they will make it harder for companies to police themselves.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  When insider-trading scandals plagued the financial markets in the late 1980s, lawmakers created a bounty program for whistle-blowers, allowing regulators to reward tipsters who uncovered evidence of manipulation.
